unnormalised: Labour Ministry Proposes Amendments to EPF Scheme
normalised: Labour Ministry Proposes Amendments to E-P-F Scheme

unnormalised: The Union Labour Ministry is considering revisions to the Employees' Provident Fund (EPF) Scheme, 1952, potentially impacting millions of Indian workers. The proposed changes, as per sources, are aimed at streamlining processes and enhancing the scheme's efficiency. One key amendment being discussed is the standardization of KYC norms across all EPFO-recognized institutions, ensuring uniformity in member identification. Currently, discrepancies in KYC documentation sometimes delay claim settlements. The matter is under review by the concerned committee and a decision is expected by 30/06/2024.
normalised: The Union Labour Ministry is considering revisions to the Employees' Provident Fund (E-P-F) Scheme, one thousand nine hundred and fifty two, potentially impacting millions of Indian workers. The proposed changes, as per sources, are aimed at streamlining processes and enhancing the scheme's efficiency. One key amendment being discussed is the standardization of K-Y-C norms across all E-P-F-O-recognized institutions, ensuring uniformity in member identification. Currently, discrepancies in K-Y-C documentation sometimes delay claim settlements. The matter is under review by the concerned committee and a decision is expected by the thirtieth June two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: Another significant aspect of the potential reform pertains to the portability of EPF accounts. The ministry is exploring options to facilitate easier transfer of funds and service history when employees switch jobs. This is particularly relevant in sectors with high employee turnover, like IT and construction. Simplifying this process aims to reduce the administrative burden on both employees and employers. The existing procedure, involving Form 13 submission and attestation, is often perceived as cumbersome. The new system, if implemented, may allow online transfers via the UMANG app.
normalised: Another significant aspect of the potential reform pertains to the portability of E-P-F accounts. The ministry is exploring options to facilitate easier transfer of funds and service history when employees switch jobs. This is particularly relevant in sectors with high employee turnover, like I-T and construction. Simplifying this process aims to reduce the administrative burden on both employees and employers. The existing procedure, involving Form thirteen submission and attestation, is often perceived as cumbersome. The new system, if implemented, may allow online transfers via the U-M-A-N-G app.

unnormalised: The proposals also address the issue of unclaimed EPF amounts, which currently total over Rs. 26,000 crore. The ministry plans to launch awareness campaigns to encourage eligible members to claim their dues. This includes simplifying the claim process and providing assistance through EPFO helpdesks. A dedicated portal might be created to track and claim unclaimed amounts. As per Section 72 of the EPF Act, 1952, the government is responsible for safeguarding these funds.
normalised: The proposals also address the issue of unclaimed E-P-F amounts, which currently total over rupee twenty six thousand crore. The ministry plans to launch awareness campaigns to encourage eligible members to claim their dues. This includes simplifying the claim process and providing assistance through E-P-F-O helpdesks. A dedicated portal might be created to track and claim unclaimed amounts. As per Section seventy two of the E-P-F Act, one thousand nine hundred and fifty two, the government is responsible for safeguarding these funds.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the ministry is considering linking the EPF scheme with other social security initiatives, such as the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) scheme. This integration aims to provide a more comprehensive social security net for workers, particularly those in the unorganized sector. A pilot project exploring this integration is expected to commence in select districts by 01/01/2025. These changes, if approved, are expected to bring significant improvements to the EPF scheme.
normalised: Furthermore, the ministry is considering linking the E-P-F scheme with other social security initiatives, such as the Employees' State Insurance (E-S-I) scheme. This integration aims to provide a more comprehensive social security net for workers, particularly those in the unorganized sector. A pilot project exploring this integration is expected to commence in select districts by the first January two thousand and twenty five. These changes, if approved, are expected to bring significant improvements to the E-P-F scheme.
